description.text:
Tooth pendants are important cultural objects throughout the Pacific. Whale ivory and bone were taken from beached whales.
Developed as part of the art project series "Ghosts in the form of gifts" commissioned by Massey University Wellington, New Zealand in 2009.
Project page: bronwyn.co.nz/projects/gifts/
The series won the 2010 Award for Open Source in the Arts (NZ)
Ghosts in the form of gifts is a series of objects that are replicas of artifacts imagined as lost, hidden or misregistered during the Museum of New Zealandâ€™s tenure in the former Museum Building on Buckle St, now occupied by Massey Universityâ€™s College of Creative Arts. The objects have been created through a process of drawing, digital 3D rendering, and finally printing with the RepRap.
The digital files for the artefacts are freely available for educational re-use under a Creative Commons Attribution Share-Alike license
Search the tag "Ghosts in the form of gifts" for other objects in the series.
Credits: Bronwyn Holloway-Smith and Vik Olliver

description.text:
A traditional Chuck Puzzle crafted in 3d plastic
All the pieces fit in a specific pattern using only 3 sizes of pieces, and a few "Keyed" pieces to lock it all together

To print the puzzle, you will need multiple copies of various pieces
6x Size3
17x Size2
1x Size2-Key
28x Size1
2x Size1-Key

I recommend printing in batches of 6
I have the pieces designed with 0 tolerance, if you have trouble with a tight/loose fit, you may need to tweak some settings

I can upload level 4 and 5 if anyone wants an additional challenge

Printer Brand:

SeeMeCNC

Printer:

Rostock MAX

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.1mm

Infill:

100%

Notes:

I used Slic3r within Repetier Host
Printed with ABS
bed temp: 84
extruder temp: 225
using a .35mm nozzle
slic3r has a setting called "XY Size Compensation"

  • I set this to -.15mm to "shrink" the piece and get a nice fit.
  • Make it more negative to get a looser fit

Designed in Autodesk 123D Design

I'm using 2mm as a base measurement for all pieces. All dimensions are multiples of 2mm
each additional piece is 12mm longer than the last
The keys are made by taking a 1mm chunk out of the sides of a piece
This puzzle can be made even more complex by making longer and longer pieces

title: Geometric "proof" by exhaustion
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: Is it possible to create a volumetric object which has a circle, a square and an equilateral triangle as orthogonal profiles? This project is an attempt at a layman's "proof" by exhaustion that this is not possible: each of the objects have one profile which is imperfect. The screenshots show orthogonal views of each object (yellow) overlaid with one of the other objects to demonstrate how they differ.

title: Paint Brush Holder for Plastic Cup

description.text:
If you're like me you have plastic cups and coffee mugs sitting around your work area filled with paint brushes, sculpting tools, needle files, pencils and other items. This 3D printable snap on clip lid is design to snap over a 12 oz plastic cup (Solo and other similar brands).

You can of course scale it up or down to fit large plastic soda cups, coffee mugs, etc.

Simple little item that will help you better organize your work area and help you to find that favorite brush/tool when you need it.

I was selling this file on Etsy and it was one of my best sellers - but I noticed someone did a knock off of it (cough) and posted it for free here on Thingiverse without even the courtesy of an attribution.

Oh well - so I'm releasing it for free here. Enjoy.

title: Mold Box Corners for silicone mold making

description.text:
This 3D printable film (.stl) if for mold box corners to aid in the making of mold boxes for those who put silicone molds.

I prefer using foam core for my mold boxes - I designed these to aid in that task.

You will need to print out four of these corners which you can quickly slip over strips of foam core to form your box with corners that won't leak.

The lines on the inside corner are fill marks to help when pouring to get the proper coverage.

The little extrusion on the outside edge is a cutting guide — you can use with a razor blade knife to quickly cut your foam core strips for your mold boxes.

I choice a hight of 4" because that height covers 90% of what I cast. But you can also stack them for taller pieces (there's hole to insert a wooden dowel for that purpose).

You can of course cut you strips shorter in hieght.

You can make a box as small as 2" x 2" And you obviously still need to hot glue the edges of your box/corner on your pour surface.

title: Benchy Simpilfy3D Wanhao I3 ABS & PLA Test

description.text:
Sarf24k request ; )
http://www.thingiverse.com/groups/simplify3d/topic:8256
A bit rushed, but hey hope it helps you and any one else whom tries this Simplify3D Gcode in making a decision. Please note most of the settings were default! Please also realize that every printer is different and have there very own quirks. this print may work really well on some and not so good on others. This file should not reflect the overall performance of Simplify3D. Use at your own discretion!
P.S. Please also double check that your printers settings are compatible or similar to my Wanhao I3 that this file was designed to run on! Good luck and if you do trial it. Please post feed back. I'd be interested to see how you got on and what you thoughts were on the finished print ; )

Very early bowls have been found in China, Ancient Greece, Crete and in certain Native American cultures. Developed as part of the art project series "Ghosts in the form of gifts" commissioned by Massey University Wellington, New Zealand in 2009. Project page: http://bronwyn.co.nz/projects/gifts/ The series won the 2010 Award for Open Source in the Arts (NZ) Ghosts in the form of gifts is a series of objects that are replicas of artifacts imagined as lost, hidden or misregistered during the Museum of New Zealandâ€™s tenure in the former Museum Building on Buckle St, now occupied by Massey Universityâ€™s College of Creative Arts. The objects have been created through a process of drawing, digital 3D rendering, and finally printing with the RepRap. The digital files for the artefacts are freely available for educational re-use under a Creative Commons Attribution Share-Alike license Search the tag "Ghosts in the form of gifts" for other objects in the series. title: Geeetech i3 pro b home position/endstop mod

description.text:
Ive noted with the Geeetech i3 pro b and similar the home position is unusual (least to me anyway), im used to my home position being platform to the front of printer, unlike the geeetech that sends it all the way to the back). Strikes me as very impractical given that you then need to reach through the printer to retrieve your part at end of print.... awkward and tbf probably a little dangerous if theres still heat lingering about the printer, not to mention it'd be a pain if you enclose the printer and need to stretch all the way into the back of the enclosure to get you finished print??, theres also the fact that the X-axis rods could potentially strike a larger print at the end of a job as the Z lowers to home (the build platform is still slightly under the x-axis in stock home position)

a simple way to set the printer so your home position is BUILD PLATFORM FULLY FORWARD and EXTRUDER FULLY LEFT without need to touch firmware,software or reflash the controller.

along with re-positioning the endstop with this part design....

swap the x & y axis stepper motor plugs going into the control board.(your x-axis becomes the front to back bed axis and the left to right extruder axis is now Y-axis)
reverse the wiring going into the y-axis on the control board (the black,green,red,blue colours basically want to now be flipped)
swap the x & y endstop plugs over going into the control board and reposition the x-endstop to the front of the printer in the new part.

If done this way your build platform will now home to front of printer instead of the back and the extruder will return to stock home as usual.

your prints WONT be reversed.
you WONT need to touch any software config files
you WONT need to touch any firmware settings

this is purely a physical way of getting the front home position ive described without effecting the printers ability to function.

the same effect CAN be achieved through software/firmware settings yes (endstop would still need moving obviously) but that can be alot more involved and a little daunting for the newcomers to 3d printing that often chose the prusa range as their first printer and have zero experience with arduino use and altering config. codes.

both left and right variant design included.

part is pretty snug fitting so doesnt shift about to much but a dab of hotglue or a bit of double sided will secure it firmly.

ps....sorry about the "lined" parts shown in pictures, they were done before installing my anti-wobble design and are only really temp till I redo in Black lol

Printer:

Geeetech Prusa i3 pro B

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.3

Infill:

30%

description.text:
Case for top-mounting MKS TFT 28 on 2020 aluminium extrusions, like used by many printers (Tevo Tarantula, Folgertech FT-5, Cl-260, Vulcanus, Sparkcube and many more)

MKS TFT 28 V1.2 is a very nice a plug-and-play touchscreen-display, compatible with RAMPS V1.4 and all MKS-Boards (MKS Gen etc.) and many more which have a serial port.
Does cost around 30€ incl. shipment on Aliexpress

Display is connected via serial port only, so you can still use your old display as usual at the same time. You don't need to modify the firmware or install drivers etc., it's plug&play fun.

description.text:
See here for brain labelling: http://academic.emporia.edu/sievertl/verstruc/Tbrain.htm
An excerpt taken from “Environmental effects on fish neural plasticity and cognition” by Ebbesson, L. and Braithwaite, V.
Most fishes experiencing challenging environments are able to adjust and adapt their physiology and behaviour to help them cope more effectively. Much of this flexibility is supported and influenced by cognition and neural plasticity.
The brains of teleosts, such as trout, share many of the same subdivisions seen in most vertebrates: a brainstem, the cerebellum, the mesencephalon, a pair of optic lobes, the paired cerebral hemispheres of the telencephalon (forebrain) and the associated olfactory bulbs (Northcutt, 2002).
The mismatch between the structural position of the fish amygdala and hippocampus homologues appears to be a result of different developmental processes that produce fish and mammalian brains (Salas et al., 2006). During early embryonic development, the fish brain arises through a process of eversion, where the developing brain turns outwards on itself. In mammals, however, an opposite process occurs and the brain inverts effectively pulling the two halves of the developing brain in towards each other (Salas et al., 2006; Broglio et al., 2010). In the brain of adult mammals and fishes, this results in key neural regions ending up in very different positions.
Northcutt, R. G. (2002). Understanding vertebrate brain evolution. Integrated and Comparative Biology 42, 743–756.
Salas, C., Broglio, C., Duran, E., G ´ omez, A., Oca ´ na, F. M., Jim ˜ enez-Moya, F. & Rodríguez, ´ F. (2006). Neuropsychology of learning and memory in teleost fish. Zebrafish 3, 157–171.
Broglio, C., Rodríguez, F., Gomez, A., Arias, J. L. & Salas, C. (2010). Selective involvement ´ of the goldfish lateral pallium in spatial memory. Behavioural Brain Research 210, 191–201.

title: Evolve  GT Skateboard Remote Trigger Guard

description.text:
This is a trigger guard for the Evolve Bamboo GT and Carbon GT remotes. It is not a perfect fit as the remote has a lot of contours, but it is pretty good. All you will need to attach it is a single zip tie which links the remotes lanyard hole with the cut out in the guard, the front of the guard should click into place.

Version 2 is now available, this update is a better fit, stronger and now partially covers the reverse button to help avoid unintentional pushes. The first 2 photos are of the new version.

Version 3 is now available, yet again it has a slightly better fit, even more finger room and a slit taken out of the top to allow the model to flex around the remote and have less chance of cracking

'Ghosts in the Window (or Wall)' is a decorative print for Halloween or fun anytime. This is a two part print that is intended to create the illusion of a Ghost travelling through a solid window or wall... because half is mounted one side and the other half mounted on the other side. Simple but effective!

Three .stl files have been provided. One is for both parts in a single print the other two are each part ready to print individually. At standard scale the Ghosts are approx. 85mm tall. Print in white, translucent natural or glow-in-the-dark filament.

Provided your prints stick well to the build plate this should be an easy print. Ghosts don't use a lot of filament (Just over 30gm at standard scale with a Raft) but as they have thin walls, so a lot of outlines, do take a while to print.

Apply some good double-sided tape or similar to the flat surfaces of your Ghosts then stick in place so it appears as a single entity travelling through the solid object. Making sure the two halves are aligned will ensure the effect looks great.

Please refer to the instructions and images for additional information... and post images of your ghosts and where they are haunting.

Note: If you like this check out the rest of my fun and practical designs.

Mount your Ghosts in a window or wall...

Apply some good double-sided tape or similar to the flat surfaces of your Ghosts then stick in place so it appears as a single entity travelling through the solid object. Making sure the two halves are aligned will ensure the effect looks great.

This is a simple radio button

A friend challenged me to make him a DJ Roomba as seen in the TV show "Parks and Recreation", so I gladly took on the project! You can see details about the assembly in this video or you can check out the whole design process in this playlist!

My design considerations for the mount were:

  • Removable: Roombas and the like are not cheap products, so I didn't want to glue or screw into it.
  • Adaptable: There is a variety of vacuum robots out there, so any of them should make a good DJ Roomba! You can easily edit the clamps to your robot's height.
  • Unobstructive: The brace should not interfere with the normal operation of the robot. All sensors, buttons, and ports should be accessible.
  • Versatile: Vacuum robots can be great platforms for a variety of projects! The brace should allow anyone to build any type of robot they can imagine!

To assemble DJ Roomba brace you'll need some hardware:

  • 1/4"-20 x 1/2" screw (x1)
  • 1/4"-20 nuts (x3)
  • 1/4"-20 lock-nuts (x3)
  • 1/4"-20 x 6" threaded rod (x3)
  • washers (x3)
  • glue

Additionally, you could print a figurehead for your Roomba's "prow"! all you need is to do add a socket for a 1/4"-20 nut in your favorite model and screw it in! You can look at my Harambe Head, for example.

Printer:

Monoprice Maker Select

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

20-30% higher for more strength

1. Screw 1/4-20 screw in hub's center hole
  2. Glue lock nuts into the slots in the hub
  3. Screw in threaded rods
  4. Insert "thick" clamps with open side facing towards center on 2 rods
  5. Place washer and screw in nut
  6. Screw in nut in third rod
  7. Place brace on Roomba and center the hub
  8. Adjust the "thick" clamps for a snug fit
  9. Place washer on third rod
  10. Insert "thin" clamp with open side facing outwards.
  11. Fit "thin" clamp to handle and screw nut towards it until there is no wobble.
  12. Screw your speakers or device of preference to the hub

Let DJ Roomba roam!

Many parts of the frog's brain correspond with those of humans. It consists of two olfactory lobes, two cerebral hemispheres, a pineal body, two optic lobes, a cerebellum and a medulla oblongata. Muscular coordination and posture are controlled by the cerebellum, and the medulla oblongata regulates respiration, digestion and other automatic functions.[62] The relative size of the cerebrum in frogs is much smaller than it is in humans. Frogs have ten pairs of cranial nerves which pass information from the outside directly to the brain, and ten pairs of spinal nerves which pass information from the extremities to the brain through the spinal cord.[62] By contrast, all amniotes (mammals, birds and reptiles) have twelve pairs of cranial nerves. - Wikipeda, https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Frog#Nervous_system

I've been looking at imported low-cost C02 Laser engravers and how people have modded them. ZeusArts has a nice 3D printed digital thermometer holder at http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1719324 along with a bunch of other great mods. Since the thermometers are so cheap, I ordered some for my 3D printer to monitor air intake temperature vs. that inside the cabinet. So here's a bunch of different sized wall-mountable digital thermometer holders. from 1x1 to 4 wide by 5 high (way overkill). These mounts have enough space to hide the connectors and excess wires behind them. Print them upside down (so the face is on the print bed). No supports needed. cutouts are provided so that the temperature probe(s) and power don't get pinched. A filler or "blank" is included to fill any as-yet unused spots. You can find the thermometers on Ebay. Just search for "digital thermometer Molex panel PC", which should bring up the one I used, along with many other probably compatable alternatives. I simply spliced a 5V Wall-Wart into the power cable to power mine. The heavy duty button on the back toggles between Celsius and Fahrenheit.
See labelled model here: http://academic.emporia.edu/sievertl/verstruc/Pbrain.htm

description.text:
Jellybean X is the coolest and the fastest pocket sized quad you can print yourself. It is just like the Skidmark X however it has slightly shorter arms and reinforced body making it a better choice for serious 4S racing. It uses the 1306 4000kV red bottom motors and small Piko BLX Flight controller. We recommend the Banggood 1000TVL CCD camera and a small VTX and RX like the XSR or Furious FrSky RX and the Cicada BLHeli S ESC's (no more than 12mm wide). Use 4 blade Gemfan 3035 fiber reinforced props. Battery 4S Joos 460mah. Build video and flight video coming soon.

Note that this is not for beginners, it has a fixed camera angle for racing. Its aerodynamics are very slippery, this thing just wants to keep moving fast !

More info available at Jellybean FPV (please join)
https://www.facebook.com/groups/720769801395884/

Developed as part of the art project series "Ghosts in the form of gifts" commissioned by Massey University Wellington, New Zealand in 2009. Project page: http://bronwyn.co.nz/projects/gifts/ The series won the 2010 Award for Open Source in the Arts (NZ) Ghosts in the form of gifts is a series of objects that are replicas of artifacts imagined as lost, hidden or misregistered during the Museum of New Zealandâ€™s tenure in the former Museum Building on Buckle St, now occupied by Massey Universityâ€™s College of Creative Arts. The objects have been created through a process of drawing, digital 3D rendering, and finally printing with the RepRap. The digital files for the artefacts are freely available for educational re-use under a Creative Commons Attribution Share-Alike license Search the tag "Ghosts in the form of gifts" for other objects in the series. author: san_chy

title: GoPro bar mount with plastic hinge

description.text:
A neat and compact handlebar mount for a GoPro camera. Only a single clamp bolt is used to attach it to the handlebars due to the plastic hinge. This is not designed for (though may survive) repeated installation & removal, since the hinge is fairly thick for strength and therefore may well break after a few tens of flexes.

Designed to fit 25.4mm diameter bars.

comments.text: Any chance you can remix this for 35mm handlebars?  Or provide the cad file so I could take a stab?
comments.author: p3ck

comments.text: Hi. What sized bolts & nuts would work with this?
comments.author: GrindANB

comments.text:
Hi,
It was designed for a metric M5 bolt and nut. I don't think it will grip a 23mm tube if printed at 100%, you could either print it at reduced scale (like 23/25, so 92%) or print at 100% and then cut or sand off part of the two faces that close together when the bolt is tightened.

This is a 3d printed thing which is used with a Lidar module.

The Lidar module that was used is the predecessor of the one shown in the link below, however their bodies look the same and will most likely be compatible. This was combined with a slipring and a continuous servo motor to provide rotation for 360 scanning.

Lidar:
https://www.sparkfun.com/products/14032?utm_campaign=September+15%2C+2016&utm_medium=email&_hsenc=p2ANqtz-9OFMJOaT1zdNT7ub5WM0LmxKAMEEqWcc1YkNd5zZJjkHQoAUnh1aLWyFhsO4idOHkHaJqctVJG2CYbgo_7rxbq7o5Z-w&_hsmi=34412462&utm_content=34411915&utm_source=hs_email&hsCtaTracking=975777ce-5562-4d11-ab06-d480a696f212%7C5104ce04-25b9-45a3-8623-a551d93949c7

The slipring is similar to this:
https://www.sparkfun.com/products/13065

The servo that was used:
http://www.mantech.co.za/ProductInfo.aspx?Item=14M4566

An optical pickup was later implemented due to the servo not having precise speed. I don't have the exact details of the sensor but it was mounted using the "opt_pickup_bracket.stl". It picks up the teeth on the servo gear. Note that depending on the material which the servo gear is printed with the IR light from the pickup may penetrate it.

Here is a video of the rotation:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GTpgX9L4r6I

Hardware:
Requires one 608 bearing which is pressed into the inside of the main body.
The slipring shaft was coupled to the main gear shaft with a fairly soft tube.
Some M2 fasteners for the servo attachment and M3 should suffice for the Lidar and main body mounting.

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Prusa i3

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

60% (can probably be less)

Notes:

I printed this in PLA however I would recommend printing the smaller servo gear in ABS due to wear.
The body was printed with supports and the flange upwards. The main gear was printed with supports and the shaft upwards.
Note that I increased the inner diameters on some of the holes as my printer used with Slic3r seems to print inner diameters smaller than specified.

comments.text: How do the wires not get twisted?
comments.author: tjmlz

comments.text:
Hey,
The slipring prevents the wires from being twisted. I see there are some Things available that rotate a mirror. This method is simpler and probably more reliable.
comments.author: tjmlz

title: Portable Raspberry Pi  with Adafruit LCD + keypad kit

description.text:
i wanted to make this box to run FPP for my lighting display and for a rugged portable unit we could use while camping.

the box takes 12v in i have set it up so i could use a drill battery to power the box the screen takes 12v and to get the 5v i need to the PI i used a LM2596

MY PARTS LIST:
Raspberry Pi 3 - choose your source (Amazon, Frys, Adafruit…)

Pelican 1150 Case - https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00013J89K/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o01_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1

display is a Delvcam DELV-HD7 i just had laying around

VELCRO Brand - Industrial Strength - 2" x 4' - Black- to mount the screen i need to come up with a better solution but this will work for mow

13mm 4 Pin 4P Flanged Waterproof Aviation Cable Connector Plug Socket SD13- for power

to get the 5v ineed to the PI i used a LM2596 DC-DC Buck Converter Step Down Module Power Supply Output https://www.amazon.com/RioRand-LM2596-Converter-1-23V-30V-1Pcs-LM2596/dp/B008BHAOQO/ref=sr_1_1?s=electronics&ie=UTF8&qid=1474291288&sr=1-1&keywords=lm2596

(4) Tiny Screws - hardware store

comments.text:
Hello Mattia,
i see you are living in Verona (or Region VR). Tomorrow we drive for short holidays to Lazise/Lake Garda (and normally we visiting then Verona). We like this city very much. For me it's great to have an espresso at the arena and for me woman it's great
to go through the shopping mile of verona. Years ago we saw the opera "Aida" from Verdi (viva Verdi!). It was great.
I know this is off topic and has nothing to do with 3D-Printing but it was my pleasure to say it.

description.text:
The round and square pieces are intended to turn THWACK! into a rubber mallet by printing them in a flexible filament and popping them onto the ends of the hammer.

They will also prolong the life of the hammer by allowing you to just reprint the pieces when they wear out as opposed to printing an entirely new hammer.

Thanks to Mr_MegaTronic for creating the original version of this spool holder.

title: ToJo baby bib clip for dummy/pacifier
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Needed a clip to stop my baby boy (ToJo) from throwing his dummy (pacifier) on the floor. attached a soft ribbon, using a bowline knot (so it doesn't come loose) then looped the other end through the dummy. The loop is easily loosened and the dummy removed, for cleaning etc. The clip slides easily onto most bibs and needs a little pressure to open it up for removal.

NOTE: Cut the ribbon/cord/string short so it cannot wrap around your baby's neck.

Mine was printed at 0.3mm layer height with 2 perimeter layers, 20% infill.

Just updated it with a picture of the fan for you!
The people who make the duet wifi recommend it with an active fan over the bottom of the stepper drivers as that's where the heat is generated. If you're not typically pushing your board too hard you might be able to get away without one but for long prints it's better to have one because the drivers overheating could cause missed steps in prints. I tend to do a lot of 24+ hour prints on some of my machines so fans are a must for all my printer controllers.

description.text:
Design:

  • Based off of Steve Belledin's update on Sword of Feast and Famine. http://magic.wizards.com/en/articles/archive/feature/masterpiece-series-kaladesh-inventions-2016-09-12
  • This is a 9-piece print made using the max dimensions on a Makerbot Replicator5...the whole thing measures 1.03 meters in length (see image for scale)

Making it:

  • Print the parts with the sword sticking straight up (see image from Makerbot software for reference). It'll make the surface of your sword nice and clean!
  • There's holes alone the axis to attach parts using wooden dowels (the Ikea furniture method). You can find those here https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B000PCEUW2/ref=oh_aui_search_detailpage?ie=UTF8&psc=1 or at your local hardware store. They add axial strength, and when you use them with wood glue they will expand and fit nicely.
  • I printed mine in ABS at 15%. There was some warping, but since it's along the edges it wasn't too bad. If you cluster your pieces densely as in the picture there will not be a lot of perimeter on the raft to lift and warp :)
  • Glue and/or putty the joints smooth and secure, add some rattan straw, floral wire, and ivy https://www.amazon.com/Bird-Fiy-Artificial-Dalloween-Decorations/dp/B015OQJFH8/ref=sr_1_2?ie=UTF8&qid=1474295834&sr=8-2&keywords=ivy and enjoy!

Flashforge Creator Pro

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

0.2mm

15%
(see above)

OK, This is a Remix. It was missing a few holes.

I confirmed the sizing of the part. Added holes for the x stop switch. Added holes to move the original z-axis nut from the left side x-axis assembly (known as the "Left bearing bottom plate 13B1-18") to the top (Left bearing top plate 13B1-17"). You will notice that on the right side of your "Geeetech I3 X" the corresponding parts for the right side already have the holes on the top part. Move the z-axis nut to the upper parts and your prints will have less horizontal lines on it, because you have moved the z-axis nuts further away from the z-axis motors.

author: lalakiss

description.text:
I was tired of replacing the AAA battery in my noise cancelling headphones. This thing replaces the AAA battery and gets power from a USB port on the computer the headphones are connected to. Now i have un-interrupted noise-cancelling and i can forget about the batteries!  
Note that this is only practical if your headphone battery compartment is located in-line on the cord.  
I didn't include any capacitors because i didn't think they would easily fit inside the battery. i'm not worried about it since USB power is pretty clean, you may want to try to include them.

Pint thing with raft and supports. This is a pretty small object, so infill and resolution don't matter (mine printed in 12 minutes).   
Secure the smallest, most flexible USB cable you can find. I used an old cell phone charging cable. cut off the end that doesn't attach to the computer. cut back the cable end so that 2" of the red/black wires are sticking out (cut off the other conductors. you don't need them).   
Clean up the print with a hobby knife so that the two halves fit together nicely and the USB cable hole is the correct size. drill two holes in each end with the smallest drill bit you have.  
Build the circuit as shown. use pliers so you don't burn your fingers. Visually verify that you don't have any shorts. Plug circuit into a USB port and verify it is producing the correct voltage. (1.8V with no load).  
Install circuit into battery. loop solid or tinned wire through the holes in the end of the battery and attach to circuit. Verify a second time that you have no shorts and that it is producing the correct voltage.  
Super glue everything together. I found that twist ties worked well to hold the two halves together while the glue dries.

comments.text:
Congrats on a great Thing! I had a similar idea earlier this summer, but fed of a 12V supply (my boat) and with a micro potmeter to roughly select 3V, 4,5V and 6V. (one would then need a couple of fake batteries that were short circuited from + to -)
I was tired of constantly changing the batteries in my radio and camping lights while in the sailboat, and the capacity of the 12V batteries are for all theese purposes virtually limitless.

I originally started from the model by Cylindric, and modified it to hold the mini cards in sleeves. For this model, I simply did the math to convert a box that held 41mm x 63mm sized card sleeves to one that would hold 57mm x 89mm ones. I also raised the sides to hold more cards and eliminated the cutout on the lid (since the larger cards don't need it.

update 07.01.2018: uploaded sketch for back and helmet.

Here are my files for a complete Iron Man MK6 suit.
It looks great, but it is NOT comfortable.
And because it is halloweentime I added a battledamaged mask for the helmet.

Here is a video of the moving faceplate. Special thanks to "redeathray" for checking my code and helping me.

https://youtu.be/Wdb1UWU4UAY
https://youtu.be/P-KLNkn2KAA
https://youtu.be/ZY1E9p6GItU

The pictures show me trying out all parts.The electronics are not yet completed, but I think you are more interrested in the files.
One picture shows a small version of the MK6 helmet as battledamaged. I gonne use it as decoration for Halloween.
I prefere the MK3 helmet to wear. I like the look more.
You can download it from "jhon De Sousa" on the following link:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:260152

Most parts are founded on the following 24cm high Iron Man MK6 shell figure from "RohitVen". I asked him to rework and publish his files as a costume and he agreed to.
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1026995

The gloves are made of a Papakura file. The glove is originaly made by "zabana" and remixed by "darkside501st". Below the original link for the glove:
http://www.therpf.com/showthread.php?t=139470&highlight=hand+zabana

As arc reactor I used this Modell from "Thaurus":
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1377484

All parts were made for a Prusa I3 with a 220x220x240mm buildplate.
If you have any problems or find parts which are to big please contact me and I will do my best to change it.

Except of the printed parts, some buckles (printed or bought), elastic strap and a lot of soft foam for a little comfort you will need the following parts:

Helm: 4x M4 Bush, MG995 Servo, any arduinoor other micro controller, at least 8x LED white, 4x M4x10, 4x M3x20, 4x M3 nut, acrylglass, 2x contactor , (or 1x, depending on the sketch you use)

Neck: EVA foam for a comfortable and flexible neck (if you want to make a neck)

Chest: acrylglass 2x M4x40, 2x M4 nut,

ABS: EVA foam for a comfortable and flexible sideparts

Lower arm (each): some springs for a backflipping handplate, M4x20, M4 nut

Gloves (each): 4x LED White, 1x G4 COB LED spot, 1x contactor (to enable G4 COB as repulsor)

Hips: M4x25, M4 nut

Thigh: if you want the knee moving / flapping you will need four springs. I used a blow-dryer to make it a Little more comfortable, because they are really to narrow for my legs. But I could not resize them, because then they wont fit to the rest of the costume and it won't look good .

Shoe: a lot of foam to make it suitable.

Clipmount: it is made to attach the elastc strap. you will need a M4x25 and a M4 nut for each, you can connect the different parts by using a clips

It might be that some parts to not fit to your body. please check it bevor you print all.
I am about 1.8 meters high and I have a weight of 80kg. The following measures may help you:
head: 58cm
shoulders 53cm (from side to side)
chest: 105cm
waist: 90cm
hips: 104cm

If you got any questions feel free to ask and massage me.
I hope you enjoy it.

Printer:

CL-260, Prusa I3

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

15

Notes:

You will need to mirror many parts with your slicer. The chest, back, hips are just half models. I added a "L", "R" or "half" to mark them you will need to print a second, mirrored one for the full suit.

I tried to set a good Position for printing the parts, but you know your brinter better than I do. For example a PRusa with a moving buildplate is not he best Printer to print pretty high objects.

All made of PLA at 195°C, 60°C heatbed and 45mm/s speed.
Walls at least 0.8 mm if you really want to wear it. I used 1.2mm walls.
You will need really much time to print this suit. It took me more than 3 month (24/7) and more than 20kg of filament to print the whole suit.

Finishing

I conected the parts with a soldering Iron. You might glue it but I do not believe that it will last long if you really wear it. Than I used a 3D-Pen to make the connection points thicker.

If you want a real good costume you will need to sand and paint everything. This might be the most work. For the hole suit you will need serveral weeks. Otherwise you can print it in a better resultation. But that would need much time or many many printers.

Well...

First I found the figure of the Iron Man MK6 suit on thingiverse. As I already made an Iron Man suit of foam I was really sattisfied to find such a good model.

I used Meshmixer to make the things thicker, enlarge, resize, connect them and try to delete failures.

Hinges and things like that were made with Inventor.

Aching and braking

It might look pretty good, but because of the tough fittings and sometimes narrow parts it hurts a little at many positions.
Espacially the knee and the elbow are complicated. Here it hurts most. To drink something while I wear the suit a straw is necesary.
some parts might breakoff if they are not printed well or you move to heavy. So test everything before you paint it. this will save you a lot of work.

title: Interdictor-class medium frigate

description.text:
The Immobilizer 418 cruiser, also known as the Interdictor-class heavy cruiser, Interdictor-class medium frigate, Interdictor Dreadnaught, or simply the Interdictor, was a 600-meter-long cruiser built on the standard Vindicator-class heavy cruiser hull (later used for the Enforcer-class picket cruiser).

Equipped with gravity well projectors designed to pull ships from hyperspace and/or prevent them making the jump to lightspeed, the Interdictor became a valuable addition to the Imperial Navy.

I did not create this model. I converted and repaired this model for printing. credit goes to the following team.

author: SGRacer

title: Easy fit 3D tracks Hot Wheels attachable

description.text:
I designed this alternate Hot Wheels tracks and adapters to allow for my nephew to play with his cool original tracks & cars with the adition to play with a quick and easy fitting / unfitting of the tracks. These are not high speed tracks, these are mostly used for custom building / designing tracks, taking into account the kids little hands and needs for customization and puzzling. The adapters ase used to snap together the original tracks to this new ones. My nephew allways asked me to fit the tracks and I am tired. This way he quickly designs his own tracks without asking for any help. All parts fit in a 200x200mm buildplate. Support for adapters required. This parts prints easily, Some parts make possible a 3D track build like the slopes and building supports. Maybe you are wondering why I designed this so sturdy... Well, you don't know my nephew...

UPDATE (11-OCT-2016) Left track crossover added. 100+ parts printed. Pics soon. Also working in bodyworks for cars.

UPDATE (20-SEP-2016): Going 3D!! Four new parts added consisting on up and down slopes, and corresponding rotating building supports. All this four new parts require support for printing. Also added a stackable support multiple floors. My nephew and my printers are gonna kill me!!!

UPDATE (19-SEP-2016): As I feared my nephew started to ask for new parts, a tunnel or a bridge, so I designed a thing that could be both... Print it verticaly with buildplate only support. Holes are fine without support because they are at 45º angles. Hope this to be enough for the kid in a while, as I have no more time for this at the moment.

Enjoy.

comments.text: So maybe I am misunderstanding the description.  Do these have the ability to connect to the standard hotwheels tracks using the little double button connector as well?  Or do they only connect to each other?  Thanks!

comments.text: Use the supplied adapter to connect to standar HW tracks.

title: After Paul Maseykâ€™s Portrait of the artist on a young horse
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: This object has been developed as part of the art project "Whisper Down The Lane", currently being developed by Bronwyn Holloway-Smith in conjunction with the exhibition The Obstinate Object: Contemporary New Zealand Sculpture at City Gallery Wellington, New Zealand (24 February â€“ 10 June 2012). During the exhibition digital 3D models will be made of selected works in The Obstinate Object in collaboration with designer Ant Pelosi. The files for these models will be released for free download on Thingiverse under a Creative Commons BY-SA-NC License. Each physical work in this series is also available for purchase through a manufacture-on-demand system. The models are being produced in New Zealand using fabrication technology including the Open Source RepRap 3D printer (with Vik Olliver) and laser cutting. Order editions on the project webpage: http://bronwyn.co.nz/projects/whisper-down-the-lane The project will start with one work and will then gradually grow over the course of the exhibition as new works are completed and released. To receive notifications of new releases follow @hollowaysmith on Twitter, or join the mailing list at http://bronwyn.co.nz/contact/

author: HollowaySmith

title: Lambda-class T-4a shuttle
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
The Lambda-class T-4a shuttle, also known as the Imperial Shuttle, was a standard light utility craft in common use throughout the Imperial military as a transport for troops and high-ranking individuals.

Sienar Fleet Systems Lambda-class shuttle was based on a tri-wing design with a central stationary wing flanked by a pair of folding wings. When in flight position, the wing configuration resembled an inverted Y. When landing, the lower wings folded upwards. This design feature was implemented as a means to protect the ship's occupants as it touches down.

I did not create this model. I converted and repaired this model for printing. credit goes to the following team.

title: Lancer-class frigate
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
The Lancer-class was a frigate design armed with 20 AG-2G quad laser cannons, with at least some of these guns capable of being retracted into the main hull of the vessel.[7]

The Lancer was propelled by four drive engines and had a hangar bay area on its ventral side, where it could dock two shuttles. In addition, the Lancer has a docking port located on the top of its bow. The ship's bridge was located in the middle of the bow area, below a similar-looking computer/sensor control room.

I did not create this model. I converted and repaired this model for printing. credit goes to the following team.

description.text: Made this to hold joints.

This is the Ultimate upgrade for your original Replicator or "compatible" printer. Huge 16x16x16 inch (400x400x400mm) build area.
As demonstrated at World Maker Faire in NYC 2013.

Some basic notes on this design:
It's STILL a work in progress.
It uses the extruders and Mightyboard electronics from the Replicator 1 dual.
It is best used with Sailfish firmware.
It does not have to use servo motors and encoders but they certainly do make it print better. If you are building one this big, you might as well go all the way.
Some of the most recent mods, there is no CAD. The parts were made by hand. I will attempt to get you the info and measurements.
That said, I've included pictures and the files for the older style of 12mm rods being used for the central cross supporting the extruders. There are 2 versions, single or double rods (AKA 2 rods or 4 rods). I had massive ringing problems with the bot on both of those.
The latest design and the BOM include the basic bare bones info for using Igus brand camera sliders as the central cross.
The laser cut files are intended to be cut in material between 5 to 6.36mm thick (AKA 1/4 inch). It can be anything from plywood to aluminum. Due to the high stress at the mounting points, I do not recommend using acrylic due to the likelyhood of cracks but I did cut one myself as a mockup.
Again, if the first line didn't tell you, this is a work in progress.
There may be missing parts, incomplete BOM or other problems. I'm working to correct that, please be patient.

comments.text: I'm new to building 3d printer. The mightyboard seems compatible with the drivers A4988 and DRV8825. May I know if you tried using those with compatible stepper motors? Can you tell roughly how to wire up the motors, drivers and the encoder?
comments.author: aelicie

comments.text: Can you tell at what resolution are your encoders set? What type of drivers are you using to drive those brushed DC servos? I would like to see a video to hear the difference....I already used that type of motors and I suppose your printer is much quieter now.  Go on with this impressive upgrade!
comments.author: zebrauno

comments.text:
Encoders were set to 2048 counts/rev However, be conscience of limitations of current 8 bit AVR and firmware. To hit reasonable speeds, you cannot have a resolution greater than about 88 steps per mm before the stepper interrupts are being driven in higher order pulse modes. In short, AVR is just not the best processor for such an advanced system. Drivers are Gecko 320X.
As such, I used the pulse multiplier to reduce the pulse count to get to 80 steps per mm. In other words, the Gecko drivers let you use a very fine resolution at the motor, but then use a pulse multiplier to take the pulses from the microcontroller and make it look like it sent more steps. So keep in mind, regardless of what settings I used, your setup needs to be customized to the pulleys you used. Bottom line is to keep in in the acceptable range of 40-80 steps per mm, lower being faster but higher possible speeds.
comments.author: zebrauno

title: Super Pi Boy - Raspberry Pi 3 Game Boy

description.text:
This is the Super Pi Boy!
It's built around the Raspberry Pi 3 single board computer, making it a seriously powerful device!
It runs Retropie which provides a wide variety of emulators, all the way from the first Atari console to the Game Boy Advance, Nintendo 64, Dreamcast and everything in between!

It also features a 3.5" tft lcd with a resolution of 480 X 320, and a built in speaker which you can turn on and off using the switch on the side.
Because the Raspberry Pi 3 is equipped with a full size HDMI port you can also play on a full sized tv - especially handy for multi player games!

The built in controller is connected through the GPIO, and configured using the Adafruit Retrogame script.

If you want one of these yourself you can of course build one using the files on this Thingiverse page, or you can buy one from me ([email protected])

Parts List:

Raspberry pi 3:
http://www.exp-tech.de/raspberry-pi-3-modell-b-1gb-ram

Adafruit 3.5" tft display:
http://www.exp-tech.de/ntsc-pal-television-tft-display-3-5-diagonal?___SID=U

2500 mah battery:
https://www.adafruit.com/product/328

Tactile switches:
https://www.adafruit.com/products/1489

ON/OFF Switch(Main):
https://www.adafruit.com/products/917

ON/OFF Switch(Audio):
https://www.adafruit.com/products/805

PAM8302 Amplifier:
https://www.adafruit.com/products/2130

Mini Metal speaker:
https://www.adafruit.com/products/1890

PowerBoost 1000C:
https://www.adafruit.com/products/2465

(Ultra) Micro SD 32 GB:
I'm sure you know where to get an sd card.

Video: https://youtu.be/_vMHeCARaYg

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Ultimaker 2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

50 - 150 microns

Infill:

100%

Notes:

Remember to enable "print all at once" when printing the buttons.

description.text:
Pfaff Bobbin, lower thread spindle, sewing machine, Unterfadenspule, Nähmaschine

Not perfect, but works fine.
Let me know if there is demand. If that's the case I'll make improvements.

This is a 3D-printed quadcopter FPV frame for brushless motors.

There is a companion video where we print it, build it and take it out flying. We use 1806-size T-Motor F30 and 4045 tri-blade DalProps. During the maiden flights we try to test out the limits of this 3D-printed PLA frame to see how it can hold up to fast & acro flying. This video is here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=HoFMfQ3UW7Y

I printed this using PLA with around 20% infill.

Shopping List for the components shown in the video:

author: wazzagfp

title: Dany's Jet Pack
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
With this jet pack you can reach heights never once thought achievable. You can connect as many jet pack as your 3d printer can print! You can go with the classic single rocket or the modern dual rocket jet pack!
I'm currently printing the jet pack and will post images soon.

**UPDATE**

Quick update "Hollow" files have been added
•Reduce filament use by ~50%!

Print each piece. I printed at a layer height of .4 and a infill of 5% My print actually failed because my 3d printer broke at this point, but I fixed it by glueing another peice cut at the height were the print failed when I fixed my 3d printer. Glue the bottom of the rocket to the tank. ignore the hot glue lines, I did that to make the print hold together better. This is cleaned up and fixed later. before glueing the top part thread a string/rope/straps. This will make it easier than Threading it when the pieces are together. Don't Glue the two pieces yet. Again thread the straps to the bottom piece than Glue. This is how it should look like together. (sorry about the orientation changes :( womp) Connecting the Packs

After you adhere the parts you can glue on the connector and another jetpack if you like (be sure to use 2 straps for a single jet, and 1 strap on each pack for a double jet)

I used Aluminum Tape to add some strength and to fill and dents or holes. I later used After sanding, Paint it with whatever color scheme you want I used a Silver and red and covered that with gloss finish. At this point you can also use any stickers or paint on any details.

author: eeinstein

description.text:
I've made this knob for making it easier to handle sharp corners and round abouts while driving a manually shifted car. That is basically it.

To complete the assambly you will need a M6 bolt and nut and a M4 bolt and nut (or similar).

Printer:

Tevo tarantula

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

50%

Notes:

Printed in PLA, 195/48. First layer 200/55.

Extra material.

For my assembly I used a M6 bolt and nut and a M4 bolt and nut. I also used some two layers of 1mm foam sheets on part A and B each.

Assembly

  • Remove all supports and make sure that all parts are rigid. Use some grinding paper if the parts don't fit. directly. I made the "plug" a little bit smaller for the uploaded design so everything should fit.

  • Insert the bolts and nuts (if the nuts don't fit you can heat them up a bit but be careful not to deform the model.

  • stick the foam sheet on pieces A and B.

  • Attach to stearing wheel.

title: Harness Strain Relief for Nema Stepper

description.text:
Made this part for my Makerfarm Prusa i3 build, based on similar parts, but made to be bullet proof. Used to relieve stress on the wire harnesses; I used one on the x-carriage stepper and one on the extruder stepper. Can be used in many applications where NEMA 17 steppers are involved.  
They have grooves to allow the use of zip-ties to secure them; two grooves to secure the harness with small zip ties, and tabs to retain a large zip tie, which is fastened around the motor clip to keep it secure ; works great.  
I've printed these in both PLA and ABS; ABS is better (pla will warp over time from the heat) The versions pictured are printed in ABS and were made with the machine pictured.

Print this in ABS if possible; I used the standard settings (about .2mm layer height, 40% infill 3 shells) solid infill may be better, but my settings worked just fine.   
to install, slip the clip over the stepper; if the motor is installed, slip the wires through the gap in the clip, and you can get the clip into position with a litlle flexing.  
route your harness up against the post and zip tie in place. a large zip tie can be routed under the post, wrapped around the clip, and secured tightly (use some pliers to get it tight. trim the zip ties, and you're set)  Be sure to view the photos in the gallery to see how the ties are placed if you are confused.
